(innocently) But I don't know who they are. Buddy makes an exasperated grimace and exits, shutting do The CAMERA REMAINS on Rose as she rolls her eyes upward i dismay.

A shot of the family at breakfast in the dining room. The silence is deafening. Everyone looks depressed except Dad who is aloofly calm. Rose's head is bowed meekly over her plate as we hear the CLATTER of silverware. Finally, Dadd speaks in an almost pleasant tone.
Well, Rose, my sleep was a little disturbed last night, and so was Mrs. Hillyer's, and so was the children's. How about you? Was your sleep disturbed, too?
(solemnly) Yes, Mr. Hillyer, it was. I... I heard strange voices in the night.
(softly strumming fingers, finally) Strange voices, Rose?
(innocent as an angel) Yes, sir.
(still aloofly polite) Now Rose, stop behaving as if you're Bo Peep. Those men had a flight last night because of some female in this house, and it wasn't Dolly or Mrs. Hillyer.
(very tense) I don't think we ought to discuss this in front of the children.
(weeping, a hand over her eyes) Oh... oh... oh! I think... maybe... one of 'em... was Foster... but I don't hardly know him!
Oh, shut up, Rose. Shut your mouth and quit crying!
(draws herself up) I will not sit here and listen to you be brutal to this poor girl.
I am not being brutal to her!
You certainly are! She has an awful toothache, look at her jaw, it's all swollen.

(trying to restrain himself, aloofly polite to the utmost) Darlin', it is not my fault if the girl has epizootics -- -- The word means "an animal epidemic," and it's a pet wo of Daddy's; he pronounces it epi-zoo-tics, not epi-zoo-ot tics, and uses it to mean any outrageous human malady --

-- I am not responsible for her epizootics and I did not bring about her epizootics. Now listen to me. When I have to get up in the middle of the night and defend my home with a shotgun against a couple of damned scoundrels fistfighting in the bushes --
Scoundrels? They weren't scoundrels, they were just boys.
Boys? You say to me boys?

Yes! Yes, I say that to you, they were boys! Boy friends of Rose, chat's what they were, and why shouldn't she have boy friends? Do you want her to be unnatural? Don't you think she's human the same way you are yourself? It's the South, that's what it is, the South with its horrible traditions, of slavery and crime and the oppression of women, who are just as good as men and just as human!
(his eyes are a trifle glazed) Now darlin', what has the South got to do with this?

(in a real snit, afraid he will fire Rose) And when I try to talk to you seriously, when I try to explain to you the unlimited creative power of life, how beautiful it would be if we gave up this hopeless struggle and simply loved each other from our hearts, what do you do -- you mock me!
(mildly, his eyes are even more glazed) I don't intend to mock you, dear. I respect your philosophy. It's beyond my comprehension, but I respect it.
(head bowed, weeping in a little handkerchief) Ohhh-hh, ohhh...
(exasperated) Oh, shut up, Rose, eat your cornflakes!
(piteously) I'm not hungry. The word is hongry, not hungry.
Now you listen to me, Rose --
(with fire in her eyes) Just a moment! You are not going to fire this girl for an innocent thing like having boy friends, not while there is breath in my body!
I don't intend to fire her, darlin'.
It isn't her fault if she's popular... what?
I said I don't intend to fire her. I just want to ask her to keep her boy friends away from my home and hearth, that's all.
(simmers down at once, now calmly) Well, that's very reasonable. Howe I hate to bring it up, but she's got an awful toothache, we've got to carry her to the dentist.
I don't want to go to the dentist.
Be quiet, Rose.

Darlin', I'll take a taxi to the hotel. You and Brother can handle the girl's epizootics. I'll just say one more thing.  (turns to Rose and, in a grave tone) Rose, I told you you had a friend in Mrs. Hillyer, didn't I, that she would fight for you like a tiger?
(meekly) Yes, sir.

All right, thanks to her, and thanks to this case of epizootics, you are getting another chance.  (points a finger at her, and sternly) But don't try my patience again. We have growing children in this house. Do you understand me?
Yes, sir.
CUT TO a shot of Mother, Rose and Buddy in a dentist's waiting room. Rose is holding a rubber ice bag to her jaw which is quite swollen. She is groaning and half weeping pain.
Poor thing. Does the ice help, Rose?
Ohh-hh, a little. Oh-h, I ain't never been to no dentist before. He's gonna kill me, I just know it.
No, Rose, he'll help you. ANOTHER ANGLE, Rose shrinks in fear as, enter the dentist a white coat, DR. WINTON, a kindly-looking, gray-haired m We see a nurse behind him. He smiles in a reassuring mann
Nurse says we have a nervous patient. Now, young lady, be calm. First of all, let me tell you, I am not going to hurt you.
Yes, you are.
No, I am not.
Look, you can't kid me.
(rises, takes her by the hand) Now, come on, Rose. Stop being so childish, come on.

ANOTHER ANGLE, on Rose and Mother and Dr. Winton, as they guide and lead Rose into the dentist's operating room.- S plants her feet and her eyes open wide with horror as she sees the chair and other equipment.
I'm not goin' in there, I don't like the looks of it!
(annoyed) Rose, sit down in that chair and be quiet! We're trying to help you, you silly creature, sit in that chair!
(very reluctantly sits in chair) Oh-hh, ohh-hh, Lord, he's gonna kill me.
You and the boy wait outside.
CUT TO a shot of Mother and Buddy in the waiting room. En Dr. Winton with a little frown.
Well, she finally let me look in her mouth. Is it true she's never been to a dentist?
She was raised on a poor dirt farm. I'm sure she's never seen a dentist or hardly even a doctor.

Well, she has one mouth in ten thousand, I don't see teeth like that once in ten years. Her trouble is an impacted wisdom tooth, but there isn't a cavity in her head, not a single one. She has perfect teeth.
But the wisdom tooth will have to be pulled?
Yes, and it's very bad. It probably should be done at the hospital under general anesthesia.
That would scare her to death. She's terrified of hospitals. To her, a hospital is where you go to die.
I think you're right, it would be harder on her. But you'd better call Mr. Hillyer, she's going to need help to get home.

A shot of Daddy behind the wheel of the model-A. Rose lie pale and exhausted on Mother's shoulder on the front seat trace of bloody gauze can be seen in her mouth and her ey are closed. Buddy is on the back seat.
(a whisper, muffled by the bloody gauze) Never again, never again...
(with pity, gently) I know it was bad, honey. I'm sorry...
No more dentists, no more dentists...
It'll get better now.

CUT TO a shot of the Model-A in the driveway of the Hilly home. Mother helps Rose out of the car, but Rose can't st on her feet. Daddy has to catch her from falling. Daddy p her up in his arms and carries her up the steps as Buddy ahead to open the front door.

A shot of Mother and Daddy and Buddy on the patio. It is beautiful sunny morning. Mother and Daddy are seated at a outdoor table about to have coffee. Daddy is opening mail Buddy, in the b.g., is gluing up a kite. Enter a smiling healthy Rose with orange juice, toast, cups and coffee on tray.
Good morning, Rose. And how do you feel today?
Wonderful. Except I can touch the place back there with my tongue, I wouldn't even know I had that tooth pulled.
(dryly, as he looks at mail) Well, I know it, I just got the bill for it.
Boy, for four or five days there I didn't think I'd live. But I'm my old self again!
Umm. Well. Yes. But no more strange voices in the night, Rose.
Oh, no, sir.
Rose has learned her lesson, haven't you, Rose?
Yes, ma'am.
A shot of Daddy peering down at an old pool table in the mezzanine of the family hotel. Buddy stands by with a poo stick in hand. In the b.g., we see a black bellboy, SHADR approaching.

I see my mother-in-law's face, son. Read 'em and weep, boy, I am playing a spectacular combination, a triple. The nine ball in the corner!  (takes his stance with cue as Shadrach walks up) Read 'em and weep, boy, that's all she wrote.
Mistah Hillyer, the Chief of Police wants you on the telephone.
(about to make his shot, looks around) The Chief of Police?
Yassuh. Daddy straightens up, sets his jaw, leans the cue against table and marches toward the elevator as Buddy stares aft him. The CAMERA STAYS on Buddy.

CUT TO a shot of Buddy going down the hotel stairs. He ho onto the banister, sliding with his hands far ahead in or to take four and even five steps at a time -- it is a childish trick, the point of the game is to touch as few stairs as possible. ANOTHER ANGLE, on Buddy as he jumps down the last remaini five steps and walks into the lobby. Daddy comes from beh the desk, grim.
Rose is in jail. She bit a policeman's thumb. Come on, son, Shadrach can run the hotel.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy and Buddy in the Model-A. Daddy st grimly ahead. Buddy steals a worried glance at him.

CUT TO a shot in the local jail. The shot is on Daddy as stands before jail bars staring sternly into a cell. His hands are on his hips, his straw hat is on the back of hi head and a bit to one side. Buddy stands beside him, a li bit behind, a worried look on his face. The CHIEF OF POLI a fat man, is on the other side of Daddy. CUT TO a POV shot of Rose in the cell. Her hair is mussed her dress is torn. A little innocent, frightened smile is her face. The CAMERA PANS to include Daddy and the Chief Police.
That was a awful brawl down at the Busy Beaver, Mr. Hillyer. You know that fat Horton, the bootlegger?
Yes, I know the son of a bitch.
Son of a bitch is right, he dern near killed a man. And this girl was the cause of it all. What's more, she bit a police officer's thumb right to the bone.
Well, Rose, what have you got to say for yourself?
(coughs, then feebly) I got an awful bad cold.
(nods slowly, then with aloof politeness) That's all you've got to say, you've got a bad cold?

(coughs again) Well, I don't know what happened. They were arguin' about baseball, then all of 'em started fightin'. As for that policeman, I didn't bite him, I don't think I bit him. In dour silence, Daddy and the Chief of Police stare at R She gives them a little smile, as if to say, "See how innocent I am?" The Chief turns to Daddy and asks with dr irony:
Well, she's your girl, Mr. Hillyer. You want me to release her in your custody?
No, not really. But I guess we'll have to do that, John. Let her out. Let the crazy creature out and I'll take her home.

CUT TO a shot of Daddy, Rose and Buddy in the Model A. Da stares grimly ahead, silent. Buddy looks solemn. Rose is badly frightened and still coughing. Finally she ventures little smile and speaks to Daddy.
I got an awful cold, I think I'm sick. Daddy is silent, his eyes fixed ahead.
CUT TO a shot of the Model A as it turns onto the Hillyer driveway.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy, Rose and Buddy in the car. She tr again.
I didn't mean to bite him. He was hitting Horton with a blackjack in the meanest way and... and I bit him accidental.
(stops the car, turns to Rose) I have to go back to the hotel. I'm on duty at the desk and who knows a quest might arrive. I will see you at suppertime, Rose.
(a feeble smile) I didn't mean to bite him, I really didn't.
I will see you at suppertime, Rose.
(feebly) Yes, air.
CUT TO a shot of a shaky, slumped Rose going up the steps with Buddy as the Model A drives away. Rose is coughing, looks miserable.

A SHOT of Buddy and Doll in the living room of the Hillye home at night. Doll is half-heartedly practicing scales o the piano and Buddy is pacing the floor, hands clasped be him in something like the style of his father. As the CAM FOLLOWS Buddy in his pacing we see Waski playing with mar on the floor.
(turns around on piano stool, to Buddy) What is Rose going to do? Where can she go?
They've been in there the longest kind of time. I can't stand it, I gotta find out what's going on.
You better not snoop, Daddy'll kill you!

CUT TO a shot of Buddy coming with great furtiveness from living room out into the front hall. Very cautiously, he tiptoes across the hall and bows down and listens at the of his mother's bedroom-study. He crouches down, peeps through the keyhole.
CUT TO a "keyhole shot" of Daddy and Mother in the bedroo Mother sits in her study chair, a handkerchief to her eye Daddy sits in a chair nearby. He looks depressed.
I'm sorry, darlin', I hate it as much as you do.
(wanly) Well, she does seem to cause a lot of trouble, I admit. But she doesn't mean any harm and it'll break the children's hearts, they all love her.

It's because of the children she's got to go. I don't want to be holier-than-thou, but the girl doesn't have the same outlook we do. Morals don't mean a thing to her, not a thing, and we can't have a girl like that in this house.
Who is to say our morals are better than hers? (frowns, sighs) But maybe you're right. She could... influence Dolly...
That is exactly what I'm afraid of.  (pauses, and firmly) The girl has got to go, darlin'.
But morals come from the heart, not from rigid rules and empty laws. And in her heart Rose has never hurt anyone and she never would. Therefore, she's not immoral. Not really.
Now look, darlin', this is no time to go off into the fourth dimension.

But what I said is the simple truth. And now I see something else, I see more deeply into it... Mother has a slightly "other-worldly" look on her face. D glances at the door of the bedroom, he suspects something
Just a moment, darlin'.
CUT TO a shot of Buddy crouched at the keyhole. With grea alacrity, he jumps up and hurries across the hall and shu the living room door just as Daddy whisks open the bedroo door. Daddy grimaces.
Could of sworn that boy was out here. Daddy shuts the door and at once almost like the movement a ballet Buddy opens the living room door and tiptoes bac the keyhole.
CUT TO a Shot of Daddy and Mother. It is another "keyhole shot."
How could Rose really be a bad influence on Dolly? She has a loving nature, you ought to want someone like that around your children. Why do you think those boys and men like her?
Well, I have a pretty good idea.

If you mean sex, you couldn't be more wrong. Rose likes those boys and men, she has love in her heart, and that is what they want. It's the most rare and beautiful thing in life and that is why they follow her.
They follow her because she's a --  (he is about to say "piece of tail," but interrupts himself) -- no, I won't say that.

What she doesn't understand is that her behavior is disturbing to other people. She's young, she's got to learn to restrain the life force that's in her. Its creative, but in her case it's too creative.
Darlin', Rose has got to go!
(rises) I'll talk to her, I'll reason with her.

CUT TO a shot of Buddy in the hall. He jumps up and hurri across the hall into the living room. Again, as the livin room door shuts the bedroom door opens. Mother starts up stairs, her mouth determined.
CUT TO a shot of Buddy and Doll and Waski in the living r
What's happening?
Mother is struggling desperately. In fact she's fighting like a tiger. But I don't know, it's close, it's mighty close.
(pauses, then in a low tone, slightly wide-eyed) Buddy... does Rose really... "do it" with all those boys and men?
(aloofly, like Daddy) Doll, don't ask childish questions.
(indignantly, to Doll) Of course not!
Oh, Waski, you don't even know what we're talking about.
CUT TO a shot of Mother going down the upstairs hall. She knocks on Roses door and enters.

CUT TO a shot of Mother as she walks over and stares down shock at Rose on the bad. Rose is lying back on a pillow staring groggily at her, obviously not quite all there. Frowning with worry, Mother sits beside her and puts a ha on her forehead.
Rose, you're very sick. You're burning up. Rose, can you hear me? Rose?
(semi-delirious) What? Wha-at? Mrs. Hillyer?
CUT TO a shot of an ambulance pulling up outside the Hill house. Attendants get out of it carrying a stretcher.

CUT TO a shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski in the front hall. They are badly frightened, even terrified. The CAMERA PANS to show the ambulance attendants carrying Rose strapped in a stretcher down the stairs, as Mother h and Daddy follows, both of them very worried. Rose is conscious now and her eyes roll with terror toward the children.
Buddy! Dolly! They're takin' me to the hospital! Don't let 'em, don't let 'em! The CAMERA STAYS on the frightened silent children as the stare after Rose on the stretcher.
A shot of Mother, Daddy, Buddy, Doll and Waski in the corridor of a hospital. All look very solemn. A nurse lea them to a door and opens it.

CUT TO a shot of a hospital room. A very pale, sick-looki Rose lies in a hospital bed. The nurse, mother, Daddy, Bu Doll and Waski enter, all of them looking very grave. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE ON Rose as she weakly turns her head the pillow. Her eyes well with tears as she recognizes th children.

(a feeble whisper) Pray for me... ANOTHER ANGLE, on the nurse as she speaks in a whisper we don't hear to Mother and Daddy, obviously telling them th better go. Daddy beckons to the children and they start t leave, all looking depressed.

CUT TO a shot of DR. F. ROBERT MARTINSON, a rather unplea man with a spade beard. He has a superior, patronizing wa talking and very little Southern accent if any. The scene his office and he is in a swivel chair behind his desk. As he speaks the CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Daddy, Mother the Hillyer children.
Well, Mrs. Hillyer, the girl is strong as an ox and that is what is keeping her alive. But not many people walk away from double pneumonia, Madam, not many.
She looks terrible, just awful.
Of course she does and I must say I'm puzzled by your delay in getting her to the hospital. I should think ordinary powers of observation would have suggested to you that she was seriously ill.
She hid it from us, Doctor. She's afraid of the hospital.
(a thin superior smile) Afraid of the hospital?
Deathly afraid of it. Her people were poor tenant farmers and she doesn't know anything about doctors or medicine or hospitals.
(frowns in open disbelief) A tenant farm? Are you trying to tell me that girl is a product of the hookworm and pellagra belt?
Well, her people were very poor. She says she was often hungry as a child, and I'm sure the food she ate was pretty awful, not a balanced diet at all.
Exactly, and that's why she couldn't possibly have come from such a farm.
(icily polite) Excuse me, sir, are you calling my wife a liar?
(embarrassed) Honey, please...

(a thin unpleasant smile) It's simply that I find it incredible, Mr. Hillyer. Aside from the girl's illness at the moment, she is very strong, a very healthy specimen of a young human female -- and a comely one, too. She must have gotten protein somewhere as a young child, if only sporadically.
It is kind of amazing. The dentist says she has perfect teeth, there isn't a cavity in her mouth.
(tries to make a supercilious joke) Her entire mouth is a cavity, Madam, ha ha ha.
(dryly, doesn't like the man a bit) Ha ha ha ha. Mother frowns at Daddy and Dr. Martinson gives him an alo glance.

(with spurious dignity) The point is you don't grow up like that on a diet of sorghum and hominy grits. She got protein somewhere, she's a very strong girl and I think she'll live... despite the delay in medical treatment.
That's all I want to know.  (rises) Lets get out of here before I get the epizootics myself. Thank you, Doctor, for your discourse, it was fascinating, no doubt.
Yes, thank you, Doctor.
(as they leave) I beg your pardon, epi-zoo-tics? Do you mean "epi-zoo-ot-tics," an animal epidemic?
(icily polite, from the door) No, I mean epizootics.
CUT TO a shot of Mother, Daddy, Buddy, Doll and Waski as Daddy comes out of the Doctor's office and shuts the door
I can't stand that polecat. They ought to hang him.
You don't like him because he's a Yankee. He's a brilliant doctor.
He's a polecat, dear.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy, Mother and the Hillyer children i hospital elevator as a black elevator operator runs them down. Daddy has his hat politely removed and is staring pensively ahead.
Rosebud looked pretty pitiful in that bed.  (sighs, shakes his head) I hope she'll be all right, but I still think we ought to fire her.
I don't see how you can even think of it now. Daddy purses his lips but says nothing. It is obvious the "epizootics" have saved Rose, at least for the time being

A SHOT of Rose in bed in her own bedroom. She is propped on pillows and wearing a rather attractive pink silk housecoat of Mother's. A tray is on her lap and she is eating her supper as Budd sits on the edge of the bed talking with her, or rather listening to her. It is obvious she is well on the road b to health.

Oh, he's so kind, so gentle inside, and so unhappy with that rich wife who doesn't understand him, her being a Southerner and everything, and what a bedside manner he has got -- so gentle and kind beneath the professor way he acts!
Rose, you are too uncritical of people.

You don't know the bedside manner that man has got. Why, it does me good just to see him sit there all solemn and go pokin' in his bag like he's gonna cure me, which he did of course. And even more important he loves me, like a patient I mean, the other day he got tears in his eyes just listenin' to my heart beat.
He did?

Yeah, he tried to hide it but I saw 'em, and a little bit he says to me, "You know, you are beautiful." Now wasn't that a nice thing for a doctor to say to a patient, wasn't it? What could cheer a girl up more?
Rose, I have got doubts about that doctor and so does Daddy.
He's got doubts about hisself and that's the saddest thing of all. Would you believe that poor man thinks nobody likes him?
Yeah, I'd believe it.
Well, I like him. I used to be afraid of doctors but not any more. Why, he could operate on me any old time and I wouldn't even be scared.
Rose, you are just entirely too uncritical of people.

I ain't neither. Listen here, Buddy, besides all his vast medical knowledge, he has the most kindest heart beneath the professor way he acts -- he wants justice in the world and he's got some real interestin' ideas.
CUT TO a shot of Mother opening the front door. Dr. Marti is there-with his black bag, an icy polite look on his fa
Oh, good evening, Doctor. Rose is a lot better, I just gave her her supper. She's almost all well now.
Let me be the judge of that, Madam.
Yes. Well. She's upstairs.
CUT TO a shot of Buddy and Rose in Rose's bedroom.

Justice, that's what he wants, justice for everybody and especially for niggers. And I think that's real nice of him because black people don't have a very good life, you got to admit that, to be a nigger is sometimes practic'ly fatal, but the wife don't understand all of that, she thinks niggers are just so much dirt, which anybody ought to know better if they been on their ass their ownselves -- and that is the cause of his profound unhappiness, Buddy, that no-good-mean wife with all her Southern prejudice against niggers and everything! It is a very long speech and delivered with a non-stop vitality that leaves Buddy a trifle groggy. Slowly, he sh his head, as enter Mother.
The Doctor is here. And Brother, supper is ready.
A SHOT of the Hillyer family minus Rose eating dinner in dining room. The meal is almost finished, Daddy cutting a pie.
Is that Doctor still up there, Brother.
Yeah, he's still up there.
What's taking the rascal so long?
Honey, Dr. Martinson isn't a rascal, he's one of the finest physicians in Glenville. He studied at Johns Hopkins University.
I don't care where the polecat studied.

Sometimes the negativism and cynicism in you makes me want to vomit.  (shakes her head sadly as Buddy surreptitiously puts his napkin on table) Your real trouble is that you're anti-intellectual. The irony is women are supposed to be emotional, but I never saw anybody who depended more on emotion and prejudice than you do.
(a half audible murmur) Excuse me, gotta go to bathroom.
Now I have a plan about Rose, an educational plan. She's getting better and we don't want any more trouble -- (notices Buddy slipping out) Brother, you ought to hear this.
I'll be right back. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Buddy as he slips out during following speech.
First, those clothes she wears. They're too provocative. I've talked to her a lot about it and I think she understands...

CUT TO a shot of Buddy as he goes down the hall, eyes narrowed. ON Buddy posted in the doorway of the living room. He has hands on his hips Daddy-style and is staring sternly up t stairs. CUT TO A POV SHOT of Dr. Martinson with his black bag in and shoulders hunched coming down the stairs. The man is slinking, has quilt written all over him. As he goes down stairs he glances to one side, sees Buddy and frowns. The gives a sudden nervous start of fright as we hear Daddy's voice loud on the TRACK.

Everything all right, Doctor? CUT TO A POV shot of Daddy at the rear of the downstairs hall, napkin in hand and hands on hips. He is staring ste at the doctor. CUT BACK TO the Doctor. He glances nervously again toward Buddy. ANOTHER POV SHOT of Buddy. Looks just like Daddy, hands o hips. ON Dr. Martinson, as he looks back at Daddy.

Oh, yes. Yes. Just fine. A few more days... a little more rest... she'll be perfectly healthy. ANOTHER ANGLE on Daddy as he walks forward down the hall toward Buddy. The CAMERA PICKS UP Buddy and both of them grimly stare after the fleeing doctor.
(in a low, conspiratorial tone) What do you think, Brother?
I don't know. But you better watch him like a hawk, if he comes back again.
He's not coming back again. We scared the rascal off, son. (puts a hand on Buddy's shoulder) Come on back to supper. Your mother has a theory about how to educate Rose.
A SHOT of Mother and Rose and the children in the kitchen see a sewing machine and evidences of dressmaking. Rose h on a new and modest little dress that Mother evidently ha made for her.
You see, Rose? Now that's the kind of dress you ought to wear.
(less than enthusiastic) Yeah, it's kinda nice.
You look very pretty in it, Rose. Really, you do.
(smiles at Mother) Well, you're real sweet to make it for me. (puts an arm around Mother's shoulder) There never was nobody like you. And you don't need to worry, I ain't goin' out no more.
Well, there's no reason you shouldn't go out, Rose... in moderation.

(a little shrug) I don't want to. When I was lyin' there in that hospital bed at death's door I says to myself, I ain't goin' out no more. If I ever get outta this, I'll just stay home. Rose casually pulls the dress over her head and stands th in panties and bra, oblivious of Buddy and the children. has about as much modesty as a small child herself.
(rather sadly) Besides, there ain't no Mr. Right out there. Or if there is I can't find him, all I find is a pile of Mr. Wrongs. I ain't goin' out no more.
A SHOT of Daddy, Mother, Rose, and the children all in th Sunday best going up the steps of a church. Rose looks virginal in the modest dress Mother made for her.
A SHOT of Rose, Mother, Daddy and the children on a bench church. We hear singing. Rose looks innocent, virginal as sings. Mother gives her an approving look, exchanges glan with Daddy.
CUT TO a shot of the Hillyer family coming out of church. see them shaking hands with the Minister. Rose smiles sweetly, modestly.
CUT TO a shot of the Model A driving up in the driveway o the Hillyer house. ANOTHER ANGLE on them all as they get out of the car. Ros takes Doll's hand with one hand and Waski's hand with the other.
All right, we'll play monopoly then. Mother, Daddy and Buddy watch Rose go up the steps with D and Waski.
She's like a different person. Being so sick made a big impression on her. I really think she's learned a lesson.
Um-hmm.  (waits as Mother goes on up steps, then turns to Buddy and in a low tone) Come with me, Brother. I want to show you something.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy and Buddy in a rose garden below t windows of the house. It is Hawkshaw the Detective and his Unwilling Assistant. Daddy solemnly points to dim marks in the flower bed.
See that, son? Now this is a heel, see, and there, that's the ball of a foot. Someone has been walking here.
(reluctantly) Well, it's not very plain.

That is because it rained recently, the rain has obscured the evidence. But you could still take plaster casts of these footprints, then match up the plaster casts with whosever shoes they are, and that way you could catch him -- understand?
But how would you find him?

Well. Well, what I mean is, you could prove it was his shoes if you did catch him. But look this, Brother, it is even more interesting. Look at this mark here, and that mark over there. Now wouldn't you say those marks are the marks of a ladder?
Well, I don't know.  (trying to sound like a fellow detective, but doesn't want Rose to get caught) No, I don't know, Daddy, I think the rain has obscured it.
True, but if you look sharply you can see that those marks are the marks of a ladder. Now let's go back to the garage and see if the ladder has been tampered with.

CUT TO a shot of Daddy and Buddy back in the garage. They scrutinizing a wooden ladder that hangs on pegs alongside garage. All Daddy needs is a cap and a pipe to be a dead ringer for Sherlock Holmes. He is in dead earnest about t it is no Joke and he does not dream of being funny.

(points to ladder, eyes narrowed) See, son? The paint is flaked off here, freshly. Look at it, Brother, there is no question about it. Some person or persons unknown have very recently tampered with this ladder.
Well... maybe...

And there's only one reason anybody would want this ladder -- to get up into Rose's bedroom in the dark of night! I am going to chain up this ladder and padlock it! -- and that is not all I am going to do! Buddy stares at him in apprehension.
A shot of the whole family at dinner including Rose. Dadd puts down his napkin.

That was a delicious repast, Rose, as usual. Now I have something of grave import to say to you and to Mrs. Hillyer.  (pauses, points at Buddy)  And I don't want you children snooping, do you hear me, Brother? Go up to your rooms.
CUT TO a shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski in the upstairs. T tiptoe along furtively.
CUT TO a shot of the children going down backstairs.
CUT TO a shot of Buddy leading Doll and Waski down the st of the cellar. The CAMERA follows as they walk past an ancient coal-burning furnace and...

climb up into 'a crawl space beneath the front of the hou A shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski crawling along on dirt in crawl space under the house. They come to a floor heat ventillator grill and stop. Buddy holds his fingers to hi lips and listens intently.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy, Mother and Rose in Mother's bedro study. We see the grillwork of the heat ventillator in th floor. Daddy is at the climax of his speech.

We all love you, Rose. Even more now, since you've bravely surmounted all these epizootics. We admire you, we esteem you, we hold your hand with love and affection, we have an investment in you -- and I don't mean money, although God knows we have that, too, considering those godawful hospital bills...
CUT TO a shot CLOSE on Buddy, Doll and Waski in the crawl space. Buddy is smiling in relief. He whispers to Doll an Waski.
He's not going to fire her.
CUT BACK TO Daddy, Mother and Rose in the bedroom-study.
I mean a human investment, Rose, we care about you, you matter to us. But we have innocent and unformed children in this house and the monkey and dog show has got to stop. Do you hear me?
(meekly) Yes, sir.
(a bit overwhelmed by Daddy) She hasn't actually done anything...

(very firmly) Just a moment, dear.  (turns to Rose and almost sadly) We can't have it, Rose. Can you behave yourself -- or not? That is the question, to behave or not to behave, to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous chastity and keep your skirt down or to hoist it in the light of the moon and make whoopee -- that is the coil shuffling question.  (a dramatic pause, then points at her) If you can't behave I am going to fire you and I say it in front of you and Mrs. Hillyer and I mean it. I point my rigid finger right at your nose, Rose, and I stare unwaveringly into your big blue eyes and I tell you... this is a final warning. Do you hear me?
(very meekly) Yes, sir.
CUT TO a shot of Buddy, Doll and Waski as they climb from crawl space down into the cellar by the furnace.
Well, if she's got any sense at all, she'll listen to that.
Sense doesn't mean anything to Rose. But I think we're on safe ground now. Daddy chained up the ladder, whoever it is can't get in the house.
A shot of Buddy sound asleep in his bed in the early gray dawn. As we DISSOLVE IN on the shot, we hear a loud BANGI and DADDY'S VOICE.

Open that door! Open it up, open it this instant! Do you hear met open that door! Buddy sits quickly up in bed, at once pushes back the cov and gets out of the bed, hurriedly reaches for his khaki pants.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy in the upstairs hall. He is fully dressed and is banging angrily on Rose's door.
Rose! Rose! Open this goddamn door! Open it or I'll break it down! ANOTHER ANGLE on Buddy as he hurries down the hall up to Daddy, in khaki pants and pulling a shirt over his head.
Open that door, damn you!
Daddy, what's the matter?

(glances around at him) She's got somebody in there, Brother! His shoes are on the back porch -- there they were, naked and smiling at me!  (bangs on door) Rose, open this door immediately! ANOTHER ANGLE on Daddy as he bangs on the door. We see a frightened Doll in her nightgown in the b.g. down the hal hand to her mouth. Daddy commences kicking at the door. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE ON Daddy.
Open up, Rose! Procrastination won't help you! Finally, the CLICK of a bolt and slowly the door opens. W see a wide-eyed, terrified Rose. She has a sheet around h and evidently nothing more.
(he pushes past her) All right, where is he? Where's the culprit?
CUT TO a shot of Daddy in the bedroom. He yanks open the closet door, looks under the bed as he talks.

Where is he? I know he's in here, where is he, Rose? His shoes were on the back porch I smiling at met Where are you, you son of a bitch? In her distress and dismay, the sheet has come down over Rose's shoulder and one of her breasts is exposed.
(feebly, she is terrified) There ain't nobody here, Mr. Hillyer! Honest, there ain't!

Where is he? Where have you got him hid?  (notices curtain blowing in wide open window) Ah, ha! The CAMERA follows Daddy as he strides angrily toward the window and leans out of it and stares down. Rose makes a little whimpering sound.

CUT TO a POV shot of the garden below as seen by Daddy fr the window. We see lying on the ground BILLY, the Sulky B who scared Mother. He wears only undershorts and is groan holding his leg, which evidently he has injured in jumpin from the window.
On Daddy, as he turns from the window to Rose.
And who, Rose, may I ask, is that?
Well, it's Billy.
And what, may I ask, was Billy doing here?
(a straight answer) Well, Mr. Hillyer, Billy's very poor, he don't have no money and there wasn't no place else to go.
Well, it was a silly question.
He's a nice boy, you'd like him. He wants to be a fireman.
Ye gods and little fishes, a fireman. Put on some clothes, Rose, you're naked as a jay bird. When you're dressed, come on downstairs. I'm afraid your friend Billy is injured, where are his clothes?

(begins weeping, both breasts now are exposed) Under the mattress. I hid 'em so you wouldn't be mad. He wants to marry me, he loves me. I can't marry him, he's too young and hasn't got no job, but he loves me... now you wouldn't hurt him, would you? Daddy gently pulls the sheet around her to cover her brea
I won't hurt him, honey.
A shot of Daddy, Mother and Rose at the kitchen table drinking coffee in the early morning. Daddy looks grave, Mother looks sad, and Rose is crying into a handkerchief.

Mr. Hillyer, I know it was bad and I hadn't ought to of done it. But I'm only a human girl and I... I ain't always perfect. I promise I won't let him in the house no more, I promise. Won't you and Mrs. Hillyer forgive me?
Rose, darlin', you break my heart. But I am only a human man myself of the father variety. Rose, pack your bag, baby, as of this moment you are hired, mired and fired.
A shot of the family at breakfast in the dining room. The dissolve suggests that some time has gone by. Daddy looks bit grim, Rose has a wan and depressed expression. Mother looks worried.
(politely) Well, Rose, going out to look for a job today?
(eyes down) What's the use, there ain't none.
Mmm. Would you get me another half a-cup of coffee, dear? Rose rises and he watches her leave, then turns to Mother
It has been three weeks since I "fired" her. Is there no way to get rid of this girl? Are we stuck with her for life?
She can't get a job, it's a depression. And we can't just throw her out on the street.
The hell we can't. Rose returns with coffee and pours it out for Daddy.
Rose, you don't look well and you haven't eaten a bit of breakfast.
I'm not hungry. I can't eat nothin', I haven't been able to eat since I got fired. I think maybe I'm sick.
God forbid. You're not sick, Rose, forget it. Don't get any notions in your head, you're not sick.
Yes, sir.
She does look a little peaky.
No, she doesn't, she's fine, fine. She's perfectly healthy, don't give her ideas.
Well, I'll do the dishes, then I'm goin' to lie down a minute and rest. My stomach hurts. Daddy watches Rose exit to the kitchen, then leans forwar and speaks to Mother, his expression a bit sly.
Her plan is obvious, plain as day. She's going on a hunger strike. The question is, how do we foil her?
She's just nervous and worried. And you would be, too, if you had no job and no place to go.
(thinking hard) Something has got to be done or Rose is going to be in this house forever.

A shot of the Model A coming up the driveway of the Hilly House. It is late afternoon. CUT TO a shot of Daddy getting out of the car. He has a triumphant little smile on his face. A shot of Daddy as he walks onto the patio, a rolled-up c of the Glenville Tribune in his hand and his straw hat on back of his head. He definitely has a triumphant expressi Buddy on the patio notices it.
CUT TO a shot of the kitchen on Mother and Rose. Mother i helping a rather wan Rose prepare dinner. Enter Daddy.
(as if everyone will be pleased) Well, I have got news! I called long distance and spoke to Cousin Hop and you'll be glad to know, Rose, I have found you a job!
Tennessee?
Yes, Tennessee, a lovely state!
Well. What kinda job is it?
Ahh-hh, you'll like it. It's a fine, outdoor-type job.
You mean a farm?

No, no, not exactly. It isn't a farm in the sense that it's a farm. Not at all. It's a... dairy establishment. You'll 1ike it! I'm sure you'll like it because it's so... peaceful! Rose bows her head and begins crying.
Honey, Rose was born on a farm and has terrible memories of farm life. Now I don't think --

Just a minute, Rose, you don't understand. This isn't a dirt farm like the one you were born on, it's nice. A neighbor of Cousin Hop's, I talked to him on the phone, a fine man... it's not a farm, damn it, it's a beautiful dairy establishment! Stop crying, Rose! Do you hear me? Stop crying, it's ideal!
I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "farm" means to her?
I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay in this house forever! I fired her, damn it!
It sounds like a farm to me. Calling it a dairy establishment, that's just trickery and flummery.

Trickery and flummery or not, she's going there tomorrow on the bus! It's settled! And I must say we've been more than fair to you, Rose, it's pretty selfish and mean hearted of you to sit there and cry like that! Rose sits head bowed at the kitchen table.
I'm not cryin' because of me, I'm cryin' because of somebody else.
(stops in mid-air, so to speak) What?
CUT TO a shot of Buddy outside on the patio, listening intently at the window. He leans forward with a keen interest, eyes wide.
CUT TO a shot CLOSE on Daddy. He is peering intently at R
What did you say, Rose? CLOSE ON Rose, as she turns, weeping.
Well, I was born on a farm myself... and I hate to think of the baby being born on one. On them all. Daddy and Mother stare in shock at Rose.
What baby? What baby? What baby are you speaking about?
Mine.
Your baby?
Yes, mine. I'm going to have one.
(he is "poleaxed," staggered) Good God almighty. This is a catastrophe, they won't hire her.
(looks up, sees Buddy in patio window) Brother, get out of that window! Buddy ducks down out of eight instantly. Both Mother and Daddy, however, are too preoccupied and upset to be conce with him.
(stares off groggily into space) This is a total catastrastroke. As of this moment I am stumped, I admit, I am stumped and treed both, the hound dogs have me surrounded.
(as Rose begins crying) Poor thing, don't cry, Rose. I know you feel awful, but don't cry, honey, nobody's perfect. Who's the father, dear?
Well, I... I... I don't know... maybe it was... but no, you can't be sure about a thing like that. It wasn't Billy, I didn't know him.
(gently) I know it's embarrassing... but who were you exposed to, dear?
Well, now, Mrs. Hillyer, I... ah-h, that's kinda hard to say.
You're not going to get anywhere with that line of questioning. The problem is, what are we going to do?
That's why I'm asking her who the father is. It's the most vital question of all. Who's the father, dear?
(offhand; he is thinking hard about what to do) She already told you, she doesn't know.
(naively) But she must know... unless... unless... Rose, was there more than one person?
(weeping in handkerchief) Oh-h, Mrs. Hillyer, I... I can't think. I... I'm not really sure.
(gently, a tiny frown, a bit shocked) Rose, really, you shouldn't act like that.
(weeping) Oh, I know. But I didn't, really. Honestly, I didn't. There was only one, but he's out of town and leave no forwardin' address.
(a brilliant idea) Ah, ha! Hold the phone! No forwarding address, huh?  (turns to Mother) In the shock of this brilliant move, I forgot something.
What did you forget?
I forgot that Rose will lie like a child. She's no more pregnant than I am, she just doesn't want to go to that farm!
Yes, I am.
No, you're not.
Yes, Mr. Hillyer, I am.
(triumphant, sure he's right) All right, tell us, Rose, what makes you think you're pregnant?
(simply) I haven't had my period for three months and my stomach is getting big.
(again "poleaxed" for a moment, but pulls himself together) I don't believe it.
It's so, Mr. Hillyer.
All right, damn it. We've seen you with your clothes off around here, stand up and pull up your dress and let's take a look!
Honey!
She doesn't have to take her panties off, we can see her stomach with 'em on. All she has to do is pull up her dress and let us see her belly.
Well, all right, if you just won't believe me. Rose stands up.
Rose, you don't have to.
I don't mind.

Now, you will see, she's lying like she always does -- that belly will be flat as a pancake! Rose lifts her dress and Daddy leans forward eagerly to confirm his belief. Rose stands there with her skirt lift She has on a pair of skimpy white panties. An unmistakabl definite protrusion can be seen in the area below her nav just above the line of her panties. A stupefied look is o Daddy's face.
I'd say about three months. Are you satisfied?
I am poleaxed and in a non compos mentis condition. I wash my hands or the whole thing.
CUT TO a shot of Doll walking up onto the patio with schoolbooks. The CAMERA follows her as she walks over to Buddy, who is crouched down eavesdropping at another wind She whispers to him.
What's goin' on?
Rose says she's goin' to have a baby and she sure looks it, but I don't think so.
A baby... and she isn't even married.
That's the least of her troubles. Rose had a rare tropic disease and the little tubes in her that babies swim down are all stopped up, she told me all about it.
If it isn't a baby... what is it?

location: DR. MARTINSON'S HOME OFFICE WAITING ROOM

text: A shot of Buddy and Rose in a rather elegant Doctor's wai room. It is night and they are alone on a small sofa. Bud has a very solemn and worried look. Rose lies weeping in terror on his shoulder.
Oh, Buddy, they're gonna cut me all up! They're gonna cut my stummick all open, I'll die!
(trying to be brave) You won't die, Rose.
Buddy, I'm scared, I'm scared!

CUT TO a shot of Dr. Martinson's private office in his ho quite a bit more luxurious than his office at the hospita sober-looking Mother and Daddy sit talking to him. He alm seems to relish the situation.

I'm not surprised you thought she was pregnant. An ovarian cyst can look very much like pregnancy. But it was pure wishful thinking on her part. The girl can never have children, she had gonorrhea at fifteen and it was untreated.
(shocked, rather feebly) Gonorrhea?
Don't worry, Madam, she can't infect your dear little kiddies. She long ago fully recovered, but the disease did irreparable damage. The girl is permanently barren.
Well, that's pathetic. Poor Rose, what a life she has had.
We make our own lives, Madam. As for malignancy, I don't think so, it's very unlikely. I probably shouldn't have even mentioned that possibility to her.
(rather coldly, seems disenchanted with him) No, you shouldn't have, it was needlessly cruel. She thinks she has cancer and is going to die.
She's an adult, Mrs. Hillyer, I was merely giving her the facts.
Well, it's a disaster. I don't know what to say, Doctor, I am floored. How dangerous is the operation?
Any major operation is dangerous. However, as we know from her previous illness, she's a very strong girl.
Well, if it isn't malignant and she can get through the operation all right, it might be better than her really being pregnant. She doesn't even know who the father might have been.

Oh, it's definitely better, beyond question. A fatherless child, an ignorant girl with no job, no money, no home. It's fortunate, a blessing really, and a stroke of good luck for another reason I want to mention to you.
(totally disenchanted with the Doctor) This conversation is making me a little sick.

Honey, that's no way to talk to the Doctor, he's merely doing his job, dear. Oddly enough, in the stress of the situation, Daddy now s almost friendly to Dr. Martinson, whom previously he considered a polecat.

location: DR. MARTINSON'S HOME OFFICE WAITING ROOM

text: CUT TO a shot of Buddy and Rose in the waiting room. He i helping her lie on the couch on pillows as she weeps, a h over her face.
I gotta find out what they're saying. You lie back and rest, Rose, and I'll give you a report on it.
I don't want to know...
CUT TO a CLOSE shot of Dr. Martinson. An expression of distaste is on his face. The CAMERA pulls back as he talk Mother and Daddy.

I'm sorry the truth nauseates you, Mrs. Hillyer, because before you leave there's a bit more of it I'd like to put to you. This operation provides a therapeutic opportunity that I feel is quite important in regard to this particular girl, who suffers not only from an ovarian cyst but from a certain psychoneurotic condition as well.
What do you mean, what kind of gobbledygook talk is that?
Go ahead, Doctor, I think I am following you.

(gives Mother an aloof glance, then to Daddy) First, about the girl's history. Evidently she's been very promiscuous since early childhood, she has no control over her sexual impulses. Furthermore, she is permanently barren, she can't have children.
Go on, Doctor.
(quietly) Yes, go on.

I am thinking particularly of the other ovary. As a rule I don't believe in removing it. The woman's hormonal system is profoundly disturbed, she is subject to possibly serious depression, she loses many of her secondary sexual characteristics for example, her breasts might shrink and become flabby, facial hair might appear along with a coarsening of the features, and of course her sexual drive is greatly diminished, especially in a girl or young woman. For these reasons I am opposed to removing the other ovary, as a rule. Do you follow me?
I am ahead of you.
Then... may I speak quite frankly with you, Mr. Hillyer?
Please do.
I have of course observed the girl in treating her.
Of course.
I think we both know her.
Yes, we know her.
What are you talking about? I don't understand all this mumbo jumbo and the funny looks on your faces.

Mrs. Hillyer, this girl is sick in more ways than one. She is an extreme psychoneurotic with uncontrollable sexual impulses. It would be a mercy to spare her the suffering she causes herself and others. Therefore I recommend as a therapeutic measure the removal of her second ovary. It is ethically and medically the only proper decision in this case and I suspect your husband agrees with me.
Reluctantly, I do. It would be a blessing to her and everyone else. The girl is oversexed and I say -- spay her!

(slowly rises to her feet and in a trembling voice) Over... my... dead... body! A long, frozen pause as both Daddy and Dr. Martinson star Mother in surprise. She stares at the Doctor with fire in eyes. He seems already to shrink a little. Finally she sp with a calm fury.
Are you human beings or are you some kind of male monsters? Is there no limit to which you won't go to keep your illusions about yourselves?
(shrinking a little) Illusions, Madam?

You'd go so far as to mutilate a helpless girl who has no means to defend herself, you'd go that far? Don't you think I know what you've just said and don't you think I understand the dreadful and revolting crime you've just conspired to commit? Dr. Martinson stares at her in fear and shock, intimidate the calm fury and ice-cold moral indignation. He opens his mouth as if to speak, but no sound comes out Mother turns to Daddy.

I thought I knew you. I thought I knew you better, I thought in your heart you were a good and kind man. Well, I can't believe what I've just heard in this room. A defenseless girl depending on you for protection, and you propose to mutilate and destroy her. How could you listen even for a moment to that sadistic man?
(slightly shattered) Well, now, darlin'... give me a chance to defend myself.

I can't believe you really meant it, if I did I'd want to die. You aren't a male monster, that man is but you aren't. Look me in the eye and tell me, do you really want to take Rose's womanhood away from her when it's all she has got?
Well, I... I hadn't thought about it that much. I was thinking... well, it's an idea, the girl is oversexed, and...
Rose isn't oversexed, that's ridiculous. If you're going to talk nonsense, I don't want to talk to you at all. Rose is exactly the same as the rest of us, except more so.
Well, I know, more so. That's why I was thinking... maybe she'd be better off.
(with a quiet fury) Better off? How could she ever find love and happiness, if you did what you're talking about? Are you insane?

(rather feebly) Now, may I say, I am against that particular procedure, as a general rule. But in a case of near nymphomania, it doesn't seem monstrous to me at all, but medically advisable. Both Mother and Daddy totally ignore him. Mother's eyes a fixed on Daddy and he is struggling with himself, staring down at the floor.

Well, now, I admit... in Rose's case, it would be cruel. If Rose wasn't attractive and pretty... well, it would probably be bad for almost any young woman. I don't know exactly what I was thinking about, the doctor said it and it sounded reasonable. Daddy finally looks up at Mother and admits his error lik man.

But you're right, darlin', you're absolutely dead right, it would be an awful and horrible thing to do. I'm sorry, honey, forgive me, I didn't mean it. Mother turns from Daddy and walks up to the desk and star down at Dr. Martinson as if he is a loathesome bug upon w she intends to step.

I will not cry like a woman. If I'm upset it's because of what my husband said, not because of you. You can't make me cry like a woman, a woman has got just as much intelligence and self-control as a man. And you get this in your head. If you hurt that girl, I'll hire lawyers and sue you for malpractice for every penny you have got, I'll do my level best to ruin you. Do you understand me?
(a sickly smile, he is licked totally) Yes, I understand you, but you have misunderstood me completely.
(icy cold) I understand you perfectly. You leave that girl alone, you wretched man, or you will be sorry.

(a foolish smile, as if Mother has paid him some kind of compliment) Actually of course I won't operate, I don't do major surgery. Dr. Hardy will operate and of course he'll be guided by your wishes in this respect.

Let him be guided not by my wishes and not by Rose's wishes, although I am sure they are identical. Let him be guided by the wishes of the creative power of life itself, because that is what has spoken through me tonight.

A shot of the Model A parked on the street outside a hosp in a small Southern town. We see Daddy slowly pacing back forth in front of the hospital entrance, his head bowed a his hands clasped behind him. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSER on the Model A. Buddy sits in the middle on the front seat, Mother is at the window. Doll a Waski are on the back seat. They all are staring with pal worry at the pacing Daddy fifty feet away. All are frightened, Mother is very pale. Doll has a tiny handkerc to her eyes and is half crying. Even Waski is very scared
(seems on verge of tears) Mother... is Rose going to die?

(in a trembly voice) No, Waski, she won't die, because we are praying for her. CUT TO a shot of Daddy from the POV of the car. He looks his wristwatch, frowns and walks into the entrance of the hospital. ANOTHER ANGLE, on them all in the car. They wait, pale an silent. Doll sniffles in her handkerchief.
Why is it taking so long?

Here comes Daddy. CUT TO a POV shot of Daddy as he slowly walks up to the c his straw hat in his hand. CUT TO a shot of Mother CLOSE on her face as she stares a her husband as if trying to read the news on his face. A frown comes on her forehead as icy fear comes in her eyes ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE on Daddy as he walks up to the windo the car, hat in hand. A trace of tears can be seen in his eyes, but when he speaks his voice is calm.

(philosophically) Well, I thought I'd seen the limit, but these are the most great, gaga epizootics she's ever had. ANOTHER ANGLE on Daddy and them all. In pale fear, mother stares at him, uncertain what has happened.
How is she?
Fine. As mother sighs in heartfelt relief...
A shot of Daddy sitting with mother at the kitchen table. Bright cheerful sunshine comes in the window that opens o the patio. Rose comes into the SHOT carrying a coffee pot sunny smile on her face.
You're looking very chipper this morning, Rose. Sow do you feel?
Perfect, wonderful, good as I ever felt! Except for a big old scar on my stummick, I wouldn't even know I been in the hospital.
(with mild irony, as she pours him coffee) Well, we know you were there. The bill that hospital sent was absolutely horrendous.
(her smile fades a trifle) Well, I'll pay you that back sometime, Mr. Hillyer.
Don't worry about it, honey. Daddy pauses, seems to be struggling with himself, he is frowning.
Rose... I hate to be mean, but...  (another pause, then a little shrug) Oh, nevermind, forget it.
(in a little sad voice) What was it, Mr. Hillyer?
(rises) Nothing, Rose. Daddy stops beside her, puts an arm around her shoulders with weary irony.
We all love you, darlin'. Daddy wearily picks up his straw hat from the kitchen cou and walks out of the kitchen on the patio, as the CAMERA stays on Rose and mother.
Don't worry, honey, you'll find something.
I was offered that job as a waitress.
Forget about it, I don't want you working in one of those honky tonks.

CUT TO a shot of Buddy on the patio. He has eight or nine gourds on an outdoor table and is cutting round holes in and emptying out the seed. He glances up as Rose walks up him, pocketbook in hand. She seems a little sad. But she smiles at him.
Hi, Buddy.  (puts an arm around his shoulders) How's my sweetheart who never told on me when I was bad?
Okay.

(picks up a hollowed out gourd) Makin' homes for purple martins, huh? We had 'em on the farm. They're the prettiest things. That's what I wish I was, a bird. Just fly around catch bugs and have a lot of fun.
What are you going to do, Rose?
Take a little walk with me, huh?

CUT TO a shot of Rose and Buddy on a beautiful summer day walking in the garden behind the Hillyer house. They walk to an empty rabbit hutch. The hutch is made of rough lumb and chicken wire and has cubicles for about a dozen rabbi

(as she stares at the empty hutch) I guess I'll work as a waitress, Buddy. I done that before and it got me in worse trouble than you could know, but I can't stay here no more. Why did you get rid of your rabbits, Buddy?
They're dumb things. I got tired of them.
(smiles, touches chicken wire) Did you know when I was a child we had pretty near five hundred rabbits?
Five hundred rabbits?

Yep, we had 'em in orange crates all over. It was Daddy's dream. He was goin' to get rich raisin' rabbits. It was what killed Daddy. He didn't drown hisself till a long time later after Momma and Lunette died of typhoid, but it was them rabbits what killed him.
How did the rabbits kill him?

He thought he could sell 'em, but nobody but country folks eat rabbits, Buddy, and they ain't got no money. We had to eat them dern rabbits our own selves. Every dern one, and it took about four years to eat 'em all up.
(a little smile) Well, that doctor said you got protein somewhere and I guess he was right.

Boy did I get sick of rabbit. But later on after Momma died and Daddy wasn't doin' nothin' but drinkin', I sure would of been glad for a little rabbit stew. You know, I oughtn't to of told you about what Daddy done when I was a child. Until them rabbits ruined him, he was a real good man, Buddy.
What was your mother like?
A saint just like your own mother. She's up in heaven right now, her and Lunette, there ain't no doubt about it. ANOTHER ANGLE as Buddy and Rose walk away hand in hand aw from the rabbit hutch.
Maybe it was eating all those rabbits that made you sexy, Rose.
Buddy, sex don't mean a thing to me. It ain't nothin' but a mosquito bite.  (stops, smiles, puts an arm around his shoulders) I'll tell you a secret. Girls don't want sex, Buddy, girls want love.

A shot of Mother and Daddy in the Hillyer living room lat night. Mother sits with a worried expression on a chair, kimono around her shoulders. Daddy is pacing worriedly in pajamas and a bathrobe. He looks at his wristwatch.
It's twenty after one.
I don't understand it. Even in the wild days she was never as late as this.

I'm afraid it's my fault. I made her feel guilty this morning -- (glances around, sees something in doorway) Brother, what are you doing up? ANOTHER ANGLE on Buddy in pajamas as he enters the living room.
I heard you talking. Hasn't Rose come in?
No, she hasn't.  (frowns, looks around) I think I hear a car.

CUT TO a shot of a 1930's automobile in the Hillyer drive at night as it drives up and stops before the front steps ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE on Rose and Dave Wilkie in the car. DAVE is much YOUNGER, of course, and a rather handsome ma a stolid way. Even though he is younger than when we saw on the plane, he is quite a bit older than Rose. Rose's e are opened wide, she is a bit breathless, obviously somet important has happened. Dave stares at her as if fascinat almost as if awed.
(rather stiffly) I want to thank you for a wonderful afternoon and evenin'. Can I see you in the mornin'?
(a bit breathless) Yes. Year you can, you sure can.
CUT TO a shot of Daddy peering out of the window of the living room.
Why, that looks like Dave Wilkie,
Who?
You know Dave, his wife used to do dressmaking for you before she died.
CUT TO a shot of Rose on the steps. Happy as a clam, she turns and waves at Dave in the car, then goes on up the steps.
CUT TO a shot of the front hall as Rose comes through the front door. She is very excited, happy.
The CAMERA follows her as she goes into the living room w her big news.

You'll never guess what happened!  (pauses, then dramatically) I have met Mr. Right! I been with him all day and he loves me, I know he does, he loves me and he's going to marry met Be's practi'cly ast me already!
Well... well, that's wonderful, Rose.
And who do you suppose he is? That policeman who arrested me, the one I bit! He is Mr. Right!

VARIOUS SHOTS of a wedding in a tiny country church. We s shots of Rose in a white wedding dress, smiling, happy. D is stiff and solemn in his best suit. Daddy gravely gives Rose away. We hear no dialogue here, MUSIC on track. We s Mother, Buddy, Doll and Waski in the front row, all in Su best and very solemn. We see a CLOSE SHOT of Rose's knees trembling beneath her white wedding dress as a country minister marries them. VARIOUS SHOTS of a rather idyllic country wedding in a very plain, unpretentious country church, and...

A shot of Rose, Dave, Buddy, Doll and Waski at a picnic celebration outside the church by a running brook. The scene should be beautiful in summertime. We see a barbecue pit, homemade ice cream in the metal can, other picnic things. A happy Rose is kissing first Buddy, then Doll, then Waski. Dave smiles fondly, but rather stiffly her.
And now Waski, are you and Buddy and Dolly ready for some ice cream, huh? Do you like picnics or don't you?
We like 'em! We love 'em!
Well, it isn't a picnic, honey. It's a barbecue.
(a little smile) Okay.

A picnic doesn't involve roast meat, hon. At a barbecue you have a lot of roast meat. CUT TO a shot CLOSE on Buddy as he stares pensively at Da The CAMERA stays on him as we hear VOICES OVER. Rose is happy, Dave phlegmatic.
Well, all I know is there's ice cream. And I'm gonna have me a plate right now!
Better wait, hon. It'll spoil your appetite. Have some barbecue first. The CAMERA stays on Buddy, as he stares pensively at Dave has no expression on his face at all.
A shot of Rose and Dave bidding goodbye to the Hillyers. Daddy, Mother, Buddy, Doll and Waski are in the model A. is obviously on the verge of tears as Dave speaks solemnl Daddy.
Well, we are off to Savannah, Mr. Hillyer. No more police work, I'm getting in the construction field.
Good luck, Dave. And good luck to you, too, Rosebud.
(begins crying) Oh, Mr. Hillyer! I just can't stand to say goodbye! Daddy starts the Model A.
I love you all! Goodbye, Buddy! Goodbye, Dolly! Goodbye, Waski! ANOTHER ANGLE on Rose as she weeps and waves the handkerchief.
Goodbye! Goodbye!
A shot of Daddy and Mother in the Model A as Daddy drives see Doll and Waski solemn on the back seat, but Buddy is visible.
Well, thank God we are rid of her at last. And the best thing of all is that she's happy. The little nut is happy, she found Mr. Right in the nick of time!

Well, yes, she's happy. Of course Dave doesn't have her life force, not at all. There isn't much furniture in his house, just a table and one or two chairs, whereas Rose has furniture coming out of the windows.
Honey, he is Mr. Right.
(slowly nods) Yes, I think so. He adores her, it's almost pitiful the way he worships her. I just hope she isn't too much for him. Mother pauses, frowning, she has her doubts, looks over h shoulder.

What do you think, Brother? Mother frowns in surprise. CUT TO a POV shot of Buddy on the back seat of the car. N it is clear why we couldn't see him in the other shot. Be lying down on the seat of the car with his Sunday coat pu over his head. ANOTHER ANGLE on Mother and Buddy, Doll, Waski. Buddy lie the seat, motionless with his coat over his head.
What's the matter with him?

(seems awed, staring down at Buddy) I don't know. I think he's cryin'! CUT TO ANOTHER ANGLE on Mother, from the front as she slo turns back and stares thoughtfully ahead. The shot is als Daddy. They both stare ahead in pensive silence. Finally Mother speaks.
(rather sadly) Maybe Brother is right. Maybe so.
ON Willcox Hillyer behind the wheel of the Hertz car. He staring pensively ahead, a faint trace of tears in his ey It is a very faint trace, a look of mild irony and amusem is on his face.
(dryly, to himself) Mr. Right. Dave Wilkie. Willcox slowly shakes his head.
CUT TO a shot of the red Ford as it takes a turn-off from Interstate.

CUT TO a shot of the red Ford as it drives into a rather bustling little Southern city that does not look at all l the "Glenville" we have seen. A lot of traffic, new roads filling stations, prosperity. It could be Rome, Georgia a is today.
ANOTHER SHOT of the red Ford going past a modern Holiday in the city.

ON the red Ford as it turns into a familiar driveway, tha the old Hillyer home. But insofar as possible it looks different now, like a re from the past. Maybe the house needs painting, the garden is in weeds -- place is not exactly dilapidated, but it is marked by tim A SHOT of Willcox Hillyer as he gets out of the red Ford walks up the familiar steps of the front porch, travel ba hand.
ON Willcox Hillyer at the front door. He tries the knob, opens the door and goes inside.

CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer as he glances into the living room. The room looks the same but different -it is musty, dim. Willcox Hillyer stares at it as if haunted a bit, turns a the CAMERA follows him as he crosses the hall and looks i Mother's old bedroom-study. This room is quite different. four poster is gone. The room is dusty, musty, dark. Magazines are on the floor in a ring around Mother's old study chair. We see "male" things. It is apparent Daddy l alone in this room. A SHOT of Willcox Hillyer as he walks down the familiar h back to the kitchen.
He looks around. No one is there. He glances at a modern refrigerator that is in pretty poor shape, glances with a frown at dishes in the sink unwashed. He goes on out to t patio.

CUT TO a shot of Daddy putting out seed for birds on a ta on the patio. Daddy now is a very old man, but his personality and style are the same as ever. He looks up w a stern frown as Willcox Hillyer comes out on the patio.
Well, you rascal, where'd you come from?
Hello, Daddy. How are you?
About as good as can be expected with one foot in the grave. Good to see you, son.  (they shake hands) Did you bring any of that Yankee whisky with you?
It isn't Yankee whisky, Daddy, it's Scotch.
It's Yankee whisky to me. Daddy takes him by the arm, leads him back into the kitch
How do you stand it up there, boy, in all that ice and snow? What are you, a polar bear?
CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer and Daddy as they enter kitchen. The former opens his travel bag and takes out a bottle of Teacher's.
I can use a drink after the plane ride I had.
Your wife and children are back in New Hampshire in the snow?
(a little smile; it is summer, there couldn't be snow in New Hampshire) Yeah, they're in the snow. Willcox opens whisky, looks for glasses in the dusty fami cupboard.
Are they polar bears, too?
(frowns at cupboard) Good God, the way you live here. This place hasn't been dusted since Mother died. Look at that goddamned refrigerator.

Got another twenty years in it, boy.  (something seems to be bothering him) By the way, son, do you recall Rose, that pretty blonde girl who came to our house way back in 1935 or 1936 and caused such a damnable commotion.
(frowns, turns and stares at him) Of course I recall Rose. In fact I've been thinking of no one else for the last hour and a half.
How could that be, son?
Dave Wilkie of all people was sitting by me on the plane -- her first husband. It's funny you would mention Rose. Did you hear from her? Willcox pours out whisky.
(casually) Well, yes, in a manner of speaking. You'll have the back bedroom, son, Mother's old art room. Just be careful going down the stairs you don't break your Yankee neck.
CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer and Daddy as they walk w their drinks out to the patio.
What's all this about Rose? What do you mean, you heard from her in a manner of speaking?
Oh, I heard from her, I got a letter from her, she's fine. But there is some sad news.
What sad news? Did her cancer come back?
Oh, no, no, she got all over that. Rose is fine. Let's sit down, son.
Is her husband sick or something?

No, it's another thing. I was going to write you about it, but since you were coming down anyway I thought I'd wait till you got here. What did Dave Wilkie have to say? ANOTHER ANGLE on Willcox Hillyer and the aged Daddy as th sit on the patio sipping whisky. Willcox Hillyer is not disturbed or worried about Rose, Daddy has been very casu and offhand about it and he has no inkling of what the ne really is.
The pitiful son of a bitch said Rose was a nymphomaniac.
Um-hmm, and I suppose that incensed you?
You're damn right it incensed me, the miserable bastard. He also said the kikes and the niggers have taken over Washington. D.C.
(nods somberly) Yeah, I know, he was up here. It's pitiful like you say. When he lost Rose it ruined the man, it destroyed him totally when he lost Rose.
He didn't lose her, he threw her away.
Yes, I guess he did. He threw her away and it was the mistake of his life.

(staring off pensively into space) You know, I don't know this town any more. All this traffic, new buildings, prosperity... (pauses, almost as if in pain) Where have the years gone, Daddy? Where is the little town I knew as a boy?
At rest in the creative universe with Mother, son.
(a little smile) That's what she would say herself.
(simply, he is not emoting) A wonderful woman, boy.
It always gives me a funny feeling to come home. Dear old Southland. Gone. It's all gone, Daddy -- (a fond little smile) -- except you, you're still here.
(matter-of-factly) Not for long, boy. I've outstayed my welcome already.
It's funny you would mention Rose, I was thinking about her all the way up in the car. (gives him a glance) Or maybe it isn't so funny.
(as if in previous thought) I'm older than hell, boy. But this Yankee whisky is mighty fine, I'll say that.
All right, Daddy. We have our drink, we're out on the patio, you have prepared me for it. Rose's cancer has come back, hasn't it?
(simply, quietly) No, son, she is dead.
(numb with shock, for a moment can't speak or think) Dead, Rose is dead? You mean... she died?
I am afraid so, son. About a week ago. Her husband phoned me, she had asked him to call me if anything happened.
(in awful shock) But... but how? She was young! Rose wasn't old!

She was fifty-six, son. Of course she didn't look it, nowhere near it. The cancer came back, I'm afraid I fibbed about that. But it was very quick, son. She was in the hospital only two weeks, and the last week she didn't know anything.
(in distress, a slightly choked voice) Excuse me, I'll be right back. Willcox Hillyer rises with his drink in hand and walks ac the patio to the kitchen door.

CUT TO a shot of Willcox Hillyer as he goes into the kitc He picks up the whisky bottle and pours himself a very la drink. ANOTHER ANGLE, CLOSE on Willcox Hillyer as he stares acro the kitchen lost in thought.
in the kitchen, a sunny smile on her face as she pours co for Daddy. A very quick moment, only a few seconds.
in the kitchen, drink in hand, a look of grief on his fac He struggles to control himself, puts a hand over his eye then pulls himself together, turns from the kitchen.
ON Willcox Hillyer and Daddy as the former walks up with refreshed drink and sits down. He is in control now, his is expressionless and he is seemingly calm.
Well, you have knocked me for a hell of a loop, old man. A hell of a loop.
(simply) I know. You loved her. So did I. It was an awful shock to me, too. An awful shock. Rose was so alive it's hard to believe.
I can't believe it, Daddy. I know it must be true, but I can't believe it.

It's true, son. The girl with the cornflower eyes is dead, she is no more, Daddy pauses, in trouble emotionally, but gets a grip on himself and in an almost dispassionate manner; but powerf feeling is behind his words.

She got cancer of the breast, was operated on and had a seven-year recovery, then after a brief illness passed on in her sleep, as the man with whom she'd lived in beautiful love and harmony for twenty-five years held her hand. That is what happened, son, and God rest her lovely soul! CUT TO a CLOSE SHOT of Willcox Hillyer. Despite his effor to control himself, tears are in his eyes. He clenches hi teeth, takes a big swallow of his drink. ANOTHER ANGLE on them both as Daddy rises.
And now, if you are through with that Yankee whisky, we'll go to the Holiday Inn and get some dinner.

head_text.subj: SHOT OF WILLCOX HILLYER AND DADDY

text: as they walk toward the red rental Ford. Daddy uses a can He is a very old man. Willcox Hillyer looks in pain, he grimaces as they walk along.
Why Rose? Why Rose, Daddy?
Nobody lives forever, boy. Who'd want to?
That's a hell of a thing to say. Why, Rose?
(stops and firmly) Now look, boy, get a grip on yourself. Rose had a good life. She found her. Right, didn't she? She triumphed over everything, what are you blubbering about?
I'm not blubbering. CUT TO a shot of the red Ford going down the familiar driveway.

head_text.subj: SHOT ON DADDY AND WILLCOX HILLYER

text: in the car. Daddy is staring fiercely ahead, Willcox Hill stares ahead in gloom.
as it pulls up in front of the Holiday Inn we have alread seen.

head_text.subj: SHOT ON DADDY AND WILLCOX HILLYER

text: in the car. Willcox Hillyer sits there staring off into s in deep gloom. Daddy eyes him and now relents. We see sympathy in his face.

(gently) Rose isn't dead, son. Not really. Some of us die, but some of us don't. Rose lives. As long as some little girl somewhere gets herself up and goes out, Rose lives. CUT TO a shot of Daddy and Buddy, now middle-aged Willcox Hillyer, as they walk toward the entrance of the Holiday MUSIC.
